*Preface [#hfb94241]
Recently, to our delight, shogi is becoming more and more popular around the world thanks to the efforts by many domestic and overseas shogi fans. Delightful thing as it may, there exists a fear in our mind that the rule system of shogi might be gradually altered and its traditional aspect be forgotten in the long process of its spreading throughout the world. This fear is because of the fact that there is no officially authorized document on the internet at present, especially in English, that clearly prescribes the regulations of shogi.
81Dojo, becoming to have more influence to shogi communities over the world, here would like to take the responsibility and publish the actual rules and manners of shogi, the traditional culture of Japan. The intention of 81Dojo is not to just spread shogi, but to spread it as its genuine form.
This document is a compilation of all the "facts" that are available to know in Japan, such as commonly understood rules and manners, prescribed regulations on subtle details, precedential judgments in professional games, etc. 81Dojo here suggests that this document should always be used as the primary reference when holding any shogi competition overseas.
13th June 2011, Tomohide Kawasaki
---- **Disclaimer [#b0634270]
The objective of this document is to offer the utmost information on the known rules and manners of shogi in Japan. It is NOT the purpose of this site to be a place for establishing new interpretation and rules on yet unclear aspects of shogi regulations.
**Legend [#fe5b29c5]
To clarify how each of the description in this document should be interpreted, following categorization is employed with corresponding marks.
:Clear Rules &ref(book.png);|Generally known basic shogi rules, and subtle details that are prescribed in documents by Japan Shogi Association. :General Manners &ref(fan.png);|Generally known manners that are regarded to be proper in terms of shogi tradition and culture. :Actual Managements &ref(piece.png);|Well accepted actual application in amateur shogi tournaments in Japan, or competition regulations by Japan Shogi Association, which should be separated from shogi rules itself. :Precedents &ref(hammer.png);|Example of actual precedents that occurred in professional games in judging subtle or non-prescribed details.
//==================================================================================================
*Shogi Rules [#v73bed1e] The rules and regulations stated in this Part should be applied to any current shogi competition. When holding a competition with irregular regulations that do not comply with the following, the players must be informed equally before the game.&ref(book.png);
**1.1 Pieces and Spaces [#kbd127c8]
***1.1.1 Pieces &ref(book.png);[#dd448697] The pieces are the fundamental instruments in shogi. A piece is put on the squares on the board, and describes player's moves, which is stated in [[Section 1.3>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Move]].
Shogi has 8 types of pieces, some of them having two states depending on which side is being on top. Head side is for original state, and tail side is for promoted state.
|CENTER:Original State|CENTER:Promoted State|number per player|h |'''Fu''' (Pawn)|'''To-kin''' (Promoted Pawn)|9| |'''Kyou''' (Lance)|'''Nari-kyou''' (Promoted Lance)|2| |'''Kei''' (Knight)|'''Nari-kei''' (Promoted Night)|2| |'''Gin''' (Silver)|'''Nari-gin''' (Promoted Silver)|2| |'''Kin''' (Gold)||2| |'''Kaku''' (Bishop)|'''Uma''' (Horse)|1| |'''Hi''' (Rook)|'''Ryu''' (Dragon)|1| |'''Gyoku''' (King)||1|
Each state of each piece type has unique pattern of movements on the board. See external reference for movement patterns. ([http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shogi#Movement_and_capture Wikipedia, Shogi, Movement and Capture]) During the game, a piece is called with the name written on the top side at the moment, and can be used according to the movement pattern described on that side. Pieces that do not have promoted state cannot be used with their tail sides on top.
Pieces that belong to a player are: +Pieces on the board with their center vertex of pentagon toward the opponent +Pieces on the player's piece stand. (See [[Section 1.1.2>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Spaces]])
***1.1.2 Spaces &ref(book.png); [#Spaces]
The spaces for the pieces to exist consist of the following two.
:"'''shogi-ban'''" (shogi board)|The board has the role of dividing the game space of shogi into sections, and defines the location of each piece. A shogi board is a rectangular plane that has 10 parallel lines at regular intervals in width and depth directions each, thus forms 81 squares for the pieces to exist. No more than one piece can exist on a single square on the board at the same time, regardless of whose piece it is.&br; The series of squares in the depth direction, in other words a column, is called a "'''suji'''" ("file"). On the other hand, a row is called a "'''dan'''" ("rank"), which is in the width direction. The nearest three ranks to a player is called his "own camp", and the farthest three his "opponent's camp". :"'''koma-dai'''" (piece stand)|The space for each player's hand pieces (explained in [[Section 1.3.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#OnBoardMove]]) to be located is called "piece stand". It is used to enhance the convenience in game proceeding.&br;In principle, a player's piece stand should be located on the right side of the board from the player, also being nearer to the player.&ref(fan.png);&br; When piece stands are not available for the game, the players can agree to play without using them, in which case they must put their hand pieces near the side of the board, where both players can easily see.&ref(piece.png);&br; Any number of pieces can exist on one's piece stand, by adding one of opponent's pieces automatically after every time he/she makes a move to capture (See [[Section 1.3.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#OnBoardMove]]) it on a square.
During the game, a piece must stay on any of the 81 squares on the board, or in the spaces for both player's hand pieces. All of these pieces must be always disclosed to each other. **1.2 Game &ref(book.png);[#n7127a2e]
Shogi is a game for only the two players that face each other over the board, to compete with their abilities from the beginning to the end of the competition, making one piece movement (described in [[Section 1.3>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Move]]) at a turn alternately to aim for checkmating (See [[Section 1.5.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Resignation]]) the opponent's king first. The process of making moves until the game-end is called a "'''tai-kyoku'''" (game).
The player who plays first is called "'''sen-te'''", often described by the color "Black", and the other is called "'''go-te'''", "White".
Two players place all their own pieces that are to be used in the game with an agreed handicap level (See [[Section 1.6>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Handicap]]) and sets up the initial piece arrangement, with their head side on top, and with their center vertex of pentagon toward the opponent, so that the owner of the pieces is clear. After that they play the game with the pieces. The game is played all through with only the pieces that were set up initially. Thus, the total number of the pieces does not change during the game.
**1.3 Move [#Move] The two players alternately make moves that are prescribed as moving of pieces from and to spaces of the game under specific rules. The moves during the game are not only their right but also their obligation, thus cannot be renounced. In other words, a player must not pass his turn, and must make one move when he has the turn. At the same time, the player has the freedom in choosing his move.
A move is completed at the instant when the player's hand detaches from the piece that forms the move. Once a move is completed, the player cannot undo nor change the move.&ref(book.png);
Either of the following two actions stated in Section 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 is regarded as a move. No other move than these two can happen.
***1.3.1 On-board Move &ref(book.png);[#OnBoardMove]
This is one of the two types of moves, where a player moves any one of his/her own pieces from a square to another square on the board. Each type of piece can move only with the prescribed unique movement. The orientation of the moving piece never changes during this action.
In this action, there are two restrictions: +The piece cannot move to a square that is already occupied by one of his own pieces. +Except for Knight, a piece cannot make moves that jump over any other pieces, including the player's own and the opponent's.
Attached to this action, one or both of "to capture" and "to promote" can be conducted together. They are defined as one move as a whole.
:Capture &ref(book.png);|During the action stated above, if there exists one of the opponent's piece on the destination square, the player can make the opponent's piece belong to him as his hand piece, and occupy the square instead with his own piece that he has moved. This action is called "to capture".&br; When doing this, the player first removes the opponent's piece on the square and puts it as his own piece on his right outside the board (where his piece stand is), and then moves one of his board pieces to the square that was previously occupied by the opponent's piece. &ref(fan.png);&br; The captured piece belongs to the player as the piece written on its head side, regardless of whether it was head side or tail side up when it was captured. During the game, any piece can capture any piece. It does not happen, however, that a player captures the opponent's King and makes it as his hand piece, as the game must have already ended before that due to the rules stated in [[Section 1.5.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Resignation]].
:Promotion &ref(book.png);|When a piece that has characters written on the tail side, and is currently head side up, has moved on the board with the action stated above TO and/or FROM a square in the opponent's camp, the player has an option of flipping the piece over to let the tail side up at the destination square, its orientation still being as that of his own piece. This action of flipping over the piece is called "to promote", and the piece can then move only as the piece that is written on the tail side after it promoted.&br; Once a piece has been promoted, it cannot be back to original piece by flipping over again as long as the piece exists on the board, no matter what kind of move it ever makes.&br; The player's choosing not to flip over the piece when he has the right to, is called "to unpromote", and the piece's movement remains as its original. In this case, when the unpromoted piece later again meets the requirement to promote, it again has the option of promoting.
***1.3.2 Drop &ref(book.png);[#i615cec6]
This is one of the two types of moves, where a player puts one of his hand pieces ? pieces that he has captured ? back to one of the squares on the board again with its orientation being that of his own piece. A player can drop only one piece on each move. He may choose any one of his hand pieces, and may drop it on any vacant square on the board as long as it is not an illegal drop that is stated in [[Section 1.4>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Illegal]]. A piece must always be dropped with its head side up, regardless of which side was up when it was captured. Once a piece is dropped on the board, it moves the same as the pieces that were initially on the board, and cannot be made back as the player's own hand piece again.
**1.4 Illegal Move [#Illegal] When conducting a move explained in [[Section 1.3>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Move]], the player must avoid making any of the illegal moves explained below.
***1.4.1 Nifu &ref(book.png); [#rdfe0ffa]
"'''Nifu'''", or "Double Pawn", is a move that creates a position where two Pawns of one player exist on the same file with their head sides up. Since a Pawn cannot move sideways, Nifu occurs when a player has dropped a Pawn onto a file that already has one of his other Pawns. However, since a Promoted Pawn is not a Pawn anymore, it is not counted as one of the Pawns that form '''Nifu'''.
***1.4.2 Piece with No Potential Movement on the Board &ref(book.png); [#a0a006ba]
Such a move is prohibited that it creates a piece on the board that has no potential movement destination on the board ever. Here, potential movement destination refers to the squares to which the piece can move, and the squares to which the piece is prevented from moving by other pieces. To be concrete, a Pawn and a Lance cannot exist on the first row from the opponent's side with their head sides up, and likewise a Knight cannot exist on the first and the second row. Creating such a state by dropping or unpromoting the piece forms an illegal move.
***1.4.3 Uchi-fu-zume &ref(book.png); [#x59577f7] '''Uchi-fu-zume''', or "Pawn Drop Mate", refers to a move of dropping a Pawn that creates a checkmate (See [[Section 1.5.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Resignation]]) for the opponent's King at the very position where the Pawn has just been dropped. A Pawn drop that leads to a checkmate only at a later position is not an illegal move. Neither is a checkmate with a Pawn that has just moved on the board.
***1.4.4 Move that Lets the Own King Captured &ref(book.png); [#obf4062d] Such a move is prohibited that it creates a position where one's own King is on a square within the range of opponent pieces' movements. This refers to leaving one's own King in check, moving one's King to opponent's movement range, or removing one's piece that has been blocking an opponent's piece from capturing one's own King.
***1.4.5 Perpetual Check &ref(book.png); [#PerpetualCheck] When an identical position has occurred four times in a game, the position is prohibited for a player if his moves from the first occurrence to the fourth occurrence of the position were all checks. Here, identical position means that all of the following are identical: -the piece deployment on the board -both players' hand pieces -which player has the next turn
It does not matter whether the identical position (i.e. starting point of the recurrence) is the turn of the checking player himself or the other player's.
Perpetual Check is a special exception of Repetition Draw, which is explained in [[Section 1.5.2>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Repetition]].
**1.5 Game End [#GameEnd]
Any of the following states is regarded as a game end. Results such as the winner of the game are decided at the point of game end.
***1.5.1 Resignation &ref(book.png);[#Resignation] A player is allowed to end the game any time on his turn by declaring his own loss, even when none of the following conditions for game end is attained. This is called "'''tou-ryou'''" ("resignation", or "to resign"), and the player who resigned loses the game.
:Checkmate &ref(book.png);|When a player has made a position where at least one of his pieces ? except the King ? has the opponent's King in the range of its movement, (in other words, when he has threatened to capture the opponent’s King in the next move), the player has made an "'''oute'''" (check).&br; A state where the player who has been checked cannot remove the check with any of his next move, (in other words, a state where his King will be captured anyway on the opponent's next move), is called a "'''tsumi'''" (checkmate).&br; The player wins the game when he/she has checkmated the opponent's King first, because it inevitably means that the other player cannot make any legal move from that situation. Thus, the checkmated player must immediately make a resignation when his own King is checkmated. ***1.5.2 Repetition Draw &ref(book.png);[#Repetition]
Four-time occurrence of an identical position in one game is called "Sen-nichi-te" (Repetition), and is a draw except for Perpetual Check that is stated in [[Section 1.4.5>Rules and Manners of Shogi#PerpetualCheck]].
***1.5.3 King Entering &ref(book.png);[#yeda2e96]
Such a state is usually called "'''nyu-gyoku'''", ("King Entering"), as where both players' Kings and some other pieces have entered to the area within three rows from the opponent, so that it is difficult to ever checkmate each other's King.
In this case, the moves would continue for ever without any possibility of checkmating the King ? the primary objective of the game. Thus, when both players have achieved King Entering and there is no possibility for the Kings to be checkmated, (because that both players' other pieces have also entered the opponent's camps and promoted, etc.), the players can agree on suspending the game and decide the winner based on the numbers of the pieces they own.
Piece counting rules is such that: - Rooks and Bishops are 5 points each - Golds, Silvers, Knights, Lances, and Pawns are 1 point each - Kings are not counted
Promoted pieces and hand pieces are counted in the same way as the pieces that are written on their head sides.
If one of the players has less than 24 points, he loses. On the other hand, if both players have 24 points or more, the game ends as a draw. This kind of draw game is called "'''ji-shogi'''" ("Impasse").
//When a game has ended as a draw due to Impasse or Repetition (explained in Section 2.17.4), another game is usually then played from the beginning, Black and White switched. ***1.5.4 Loss by Illegal Act &ref(book.png);[#kcd06063]
A player loses when he/she has violated any of the restrictions stated above, which are:
:Making an illegal move|All illegal moves that are prescribed in [[Section 1.4>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Illegal]].
:Making a wrong way of moving a piece|This includes such situations as where a player has promoted a piece when it cannot, or dropped a piece with its promoted side up.
:Making a move on the opponents turn|This includes Gote's making the first move of the game by mistake.
:Changing a completed move|Player cannot change the move once it is completed, even if he noticed it was a bad move.
The player who has committed any of these illegal acts loses at that point with both players' confirmation on it, only if the result of the game (win/loss, or draw) has not yet been confirmed by other means. &ref(piece.png); (See [[Section 2.3.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Confirmation]])
***1.5.5 Time-up Loss &ref(piece.png);[#TimeUp] In addition to the above, a "time-up" is also one of the types of game end, if the game is played under a time rule. (This will be explained in [[Section 2.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#ThinkingTime]].) **1.6 Handicaps &ref(piece.png); [#Handicap] Handicap is a condition setting before the game, which is based on the difference in playing strength between the players. The only differences that can be set in the conditions are: +Which player has the first turn to play +How much is the difference in the initial numbers of the pieces
All other conditions stated so far do not change as it would alter the game concept of shogi and undermine the equality of two players.
Shogi game is generally played with 20 pieces set up for each player, which is called "'''hira-te'''" ("Even Game"), where sen-te and go-te are decided with a Pawn Toss. (See [[Section 3.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#StartGame]]) There is also a handicap called "'''jou-sen'''" ("Fixed Black"), where one of the player (the lower ranked of the two) always plays first. As the difference in playing strength widens, the handicap level is enlarged accordingly by removing some of the pieces of the higher ranked player before starting the game. The player who has his piece removed is called "'''uwa-te'''" ("Handicap Giver"), and the other is called "'''shita-te'''" ("Handicap Taker"). The removed pieces are never used in that game. The Handicap Giver should put those pieces back to the piece box before starting the game. In handicaps where some pieces are removed, the Handicap Giver always plays first, although he/she is called by the color "White" in this case for notation reasons.
Handicap types and their standard rank difference -Even Game (with Pawn Toss) … equal rank -Even Game (Fixed Black) … 1-rank difference -Lance Handicap (left Lance removed) … 2-rank difference -Bishop Handicap (Bishop removed) … 3-rank difference -Rook Handicap (Rook removed) … 4-rank difference -Rook-Lance Handicap (Rook, left Lance removed) … 5-rank difference -2-piece Handicap (Rook, Bishop removed) … 6 to 7-rank difference -4-piece Handicap (Rook, Bishop, Lances removed) … 8 to 9-rank difference -6-piece Handicap (Rook, Bishop, Lances, Knights removed) … 10-rank difference
Only the handicaps that are prescribed in Japan Shogi Association's regulation are listed above, although there are other handicap types as well.
All other rules stated so far basically do not change even in handicaps. In point rules in King Entering, however, the points for the removed pieces are added to the handicap giver’s points. *General Competition Rules [#g7fe11d5] **2.1 Thinking Time &ref(piece.png); [#ThinkingTime] In shogi the game will not end unless the players make moves. Since the players cannot be forced to make moves, "thinking time" rule is commonly employed in official competitions, regardless of its being professional or amateur, so that the game proceeds smoothly under equal condition for the players and that the game ends in time as scheduled. Thinking time is usually set before the game as the total available time for each player to use for his turns all through the game. In principle, both players are given equal thinking time, and the consumed time for each turn is subtracted from the players thinking time. As the instrument to measure time, a stopwatch is mainly used in professional competition. In amateur competition, however, a chess clock is rather commonly used. A chess clock is such a device that if one player pushes the button after making his/her move, the clock for the other player starts counting. In other words, one of the two clocks that is for the player who has the turn automatically counts. Thinking time rule systems are roughly classified into "'''byo-yomi'''" ("Extra Time Count") rule and "'''kire-make'''" ("Run-out and Lose") rule.
***2.1.1 Byo-yomi [#v21b65d2]
In this rule, once the given thinking time on the chess clock has run out, a third person (time keeper) counts Byoyomi. However, when chess clocks with Byoyomi function is available, no timer keeper is needed. When the thinking time of a player has run out, the time keeper declares to the player that counting of Byoyomi has started. Time keeper is recommended to use a stopwatch to count Byoyomi, but a wristwatch etc. can be also used if no stopwatch is available. Although Byoyomi is usually 30 seconds or 60 seconds, it can be any length such as 40 seconds etc., and it should be informed to the players beforehand. Byoyomi is counted loud enough to be heard by the players, such as "30 seconds, 40 seconds, 50 seconds, 1, 2, 3, , , 7, 8, 9," in 60 seconds Byoyomi case, for example. Time keeper mechanically counts Byoyomi until the player's move completes. If "10" was counted at last before a move is completed, the player who has had the turn loses due to time-up. Incidentally, if by any chance the piece slipped away from the hand when trying to make a move right before Byoyomi runs out, an alternative action is available for the player to express his next move, in which he points the destination square with his finger and say the name of the piece that he moves/drops to there. When this has happened, counting of Byoyomi is suspended until the current position with the last move is reproduced with the actual pieces on the board. After it is reproduced, time counting restarts for the next player to play.
***2.1.2 Kire-make [#g02298b8] Although this is a rather harsh rule where the player loses immediately when his thinking time has run out, it is becoming more often adopted recently as chess clocks become commonplace, since this rule is more suitable for competitions that need to proceed as scheduled. Even if the player has read the moves to checkmate the opponent's King in his mind, he loses when his thinking time runs out during the moves for the checkmate. Also, even if time-up is noticed after a checkmate is made, it should be rational rather to regard it as a time-up loss, as it is difficult to know when exactly the time ran out. In other words, the player's checkmating move does not become valid until he pushes the clock button after making the move. However, when time-up is noticed after the opponent made an illegal move, the opponent loses due to the illegal move.
***2.1.3 Rules regarding chess clock usage [#d5dabcea] -Chess clock should be placed on such a position that it is easily recognized by both players, is stably placed, and is in equal distance from both players where they can push button easily. -The player who plays second has the right to decide whether the clock is placed on his right or on his left. -A player's thinking time is counted with one of the clocks that is nearer to him. -To start the game, the player who plays second pushes his/her button on the clock first and starts the other clock for the opponent. -For the rest of the moves, each player pushes his/her clock button every time his/her move is made. When doing this, the player must push the button with the same hand (right or left) that he/she used to make the move. This is an important rule, because if the player makes a move with one hand and pushes the button with the other when thinking time is about to run out, fairness in counting thinking time will be undermined. -After a player has completed a move, he/she always has the right to push the button once, even if the opponent has made the next move before doing so. However, a player cannot push the button more than once in one turn, even if he/she did not or forgot to push it in his/her earlier turns. -Except for special cases such as when a notator or a time keeper is attending, the button must be always pushed by its player. The player him/herself is responsible for his/her own thinking time. -If a player arrived late for the game, the time until then is subtracted form his/her thinking time, and then the game starts. Also, it should be decided beforehand that if a player is late for more than a specific length of time, he/she loses by default. (It is possible that both players lose by default, if they both are late.) -It is often misunderstood that the completion of the move is when the button is pushed, and thus the move can be altered if the button is not pushed yet. Since completion of the move is when the player's fingers detached from the piece (as stated earlier), altering the move is considered to be illegal even when it is before pushing the button. Pushing the button should be considered to be apart from the completion of a move. Although chess clock is an important instrument, it only plays a supplementary role in the proceedings of the moves. -For the same reason, it is not prohibited to make the next move when the opponent has been forgetting to push the button after his/her move. -Once the game has ended, both clocks are stopped, and thinking time will not be counted any more. -A rematch after draw game should be played with the remaining thinking time. However, if one of the players has extremely small amount of time left (less than 10 minutes, for example), same amount of additional time is added to both players' thinking time, so that the player who had less thinking time has at least a specific amount of thinking time to start from.
**2.2 27-point Declare System &ref(piece.png);[#n0c5f324]
In order to eliminate any possibility of Impasse draw game, "27-point Rule" is employed in amateur championships today for King Entering games. In 27-point Rule, the player who has less than 27 points loses the King Entering game, as both players have 27 points each at the initial position. If both players have 27 points, White player wins.
Declare System is employed to clarify at which position the pieces should be counted.
The declarer (the player who seeks to declare win), while having the turn to play, first announces his will to declare win before making his next move. And then, he stops the clock and suspends the game.
If the position at that point meets all the requirements listed below, the declarer wins the game.
+Declarer's King is in the opponent's camp. +Declarer has at least 28 points if Black, 27 points if White. +The pieces to be counted are only those in the opponent's camp, and his hand pieces. +Declarer has at least 10 pieces in the opponent's camp other than his King. +Declarer has his thinking time or Byo-yomi left. +Declarer's King is not in check.
If any of the above requirements is not met, the declarer loses the game.
**2.3 Rights and Responsibilities of Players and Third Person &ref(piece.png); [#q4ebd14c]
***2.3.1 Confirmation of Game End [#Confirmation]
When ending the game with any of the conditions stated in [[Section 1.5>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Illegal]], both players' confirmation and agreement on their responsibility is always required.
To do this, however, player may also consult a third person (e.g. the notator) for matters that cannot be confirmed immediately, such as Repetition Draw and Perpetual Check. When the remaining time is extremely small and confirmation is difficult to make, player may stop his/her own clock and make the confirmation.
When a notator attends the game, it is his/her obligation to point out time-up.
Since players' own confirmation is always the primary factor in deciding the result of the game, it can never be changed after once confirmed by both players, even if an illegal act is found after their first agreement. Thus, an already made resignation or agreement has the strongest effect.
&br;
> >> '''Precedent: Kubo vs Gouda (5th Dec. 2006)''' &ref(hammer.png); -When both players cannot agree on the result, it should be consulted with a person who has the authority. (Also see [[Appendix Chapter 3, Article 8, Clause 4 >Rules and Manners of Shogi#A-3-8]]) -Any forced game end should be pointed out before a resignation.
> >> In Gouda's 126th move, Kubo believed that Byoyomi had run out before the move was made. But since the notator did not declare time-up and Kubo himself was in Byoyomi as well, he could not make up his mind to point it out at the time and kept playing. After 182nd move, where Kubo was in a losing position, he asked to suspend the game and pointed out that 126th move was a time-up. The notator consulted JSA Vice Chairman Makoto Nakahara with the matter. Nakahara's judgement was that pointing out time-up later is not valid. The game was then restarted, right after which Kubo resigned.
&br;
> >> '''Precedent: Abe vs Katou (10th May 2005)''' &ref(hammer.png); -An already made resignation or agreement has the strongest effect.
> >> Right after Katou played △N-37= in 100th move, he kept on fiddling with the Knight touching it again and again for several seconds, and then flipped it over to be △N-37+. Abe, instead of claiming an illegal act of changing a completed move, only claimed that thinking time should be properly subtracted because the clock had stopped since when Katou played △N-37=. Thinking time was then subtracted, and the game kept on proceeding, in which Abe resigned in the end. JSA later imposed penalty on Katou for making the illegal act of changing a completed move. However, the result of the game remained as Katou's win. ***2.3.2 Voluntary Advice by Third Person [#z94fe89f]
Any third person (e.g. spectators) must not give any advice to players.
However, he/she does have the right to point out any forced game end when it is clear, such as illegal move and time-up, etc.&ref(book.png); It should then be followed by both players' confirmation to decide the result of the game.
&br;
> >> '''Precedent: Ariyoshi vs Tanaka (TV broadcast "Haya-zashi" (Blitz) Championship)''' &ref(hammer.png); -A third person can point out illegal move.
> >> After Ariyoshi made a Nifu in the game, Tanaka kept thinking for the next move not noticing it was Nifu. The notator, Woman Professional Player Yamato Takahashi, then declared a game end based on the illegal move. *Traditional Procedures & Cultural Manners [#v4acf661]
**3.1 Starting the Game [#StartGame] +Usually, one of the two players acts as the "superior player" all through the game. Superior usually means the higher ranked or the elder. +The superior player of the two takes the seat of honor, if there is one. +The superior player opens the piece box, and gently spreads the pieces near on the center of the board. +The superior player first puts his King ("'''Oushou'''", the higher ranked King piece) to the specified square.&ref(fan.png); +The other player should wait quietly without touching any of the pieces. Only after the superior player has put his King, then he may take his King ("'''Gyoku-shou'''", the lower ranked King piece) and put it.&ref(fan.png); +There is no rule regarding how to set up other pieces than the Kings. In professional world, however, Oh-hashi Style or Itoh Style is usually used to set up the pieces in order.&ref(fan.png); (See external reference: [[Wikipedia, Shogi, Piece Setup Order>http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E9%A7%92_(%E5%B0%86%E6%A3%8B)#.E4.B8.A6.E3.81.B9.E6.96.B9.E3.81.AE.E4.BD.9C.E6.B3.95]]) +A player should set up only his own pieces. It is against manner to setup the opponent's pieces.&ref(fan.png); +After both players have put all their pieces to the initial position, the superior player puts the rest of the pieces back to the piece box, and puts it away. If the game is with a handicap, the superior player also removes some of his own pieces as well and put them in the piece box. In professional games, the piece box is usually put under the board. +In case of an Even Game, the superior player makes a "'''furi-goma'''" (Pawn Toss), and decides who plays first. To make a Pawn Toss, the player picks up five Pawns of his (usually the center pawns), and shakes them in his hands, and then throws it on the board or any plane near the players.&ref(fan.png);&br; If the number of the pieces with their head sides up is more than that of tail sides up, then the player who made the Pawn Toss plays first, and vice versa. If any piece stands on its edge or some pieces are stacked, all of those pieces are not counted. And if the numbers of heads and tails were the same, the player tosses all five Pawns again. &ref(piece.png); +The players make polite greetings, and then start the game. "'''Onegai-shimasu.'''" (or "'''Yoroshiku onegai-shimasu.'''") is the common Japanese word for greetings.&ref(fan.png);
**3.2 During the Game [#m2ea5aba]
+While thinking for the next move, a player should not keep holding his hand pieces in his hand, nor be touching the pieces on the board (except for when rearranging the positions of pieces that are disturbed.) A hand piece should be held only when it is about to be dropped. Also, a player should not repeat the action of making the same move, snapping the piece to the board again and again.&ref(fan.png); +Player's fingers should be released from the piece immediately after a move is made.&ref(fan.png); +One should start moving his piece only after the opponent's move is completed. It is impolite to start making a move before the opponent's finger detach from his piece.&ref(fan.png); +When capturing an opponent's piece, one should first gently pick up and place it on his piece stand, and then move his own piece to there.&ref(fan.png);&br; During this action, it is disgraceful to put the opponent's piece back to its square and think again, although the move is not considered to be completed at this point according to the rules. One should think carefully enough before making any action.&ref(fan.png);&br; +Player should not use both hands when capturing a piece. (Especially in a game with chess clocks.&ref(piece.png); ) +Hand pieces should be placed with their head sides up, and be arranged neatly so that the opponent can easily see them. The orientation of the hand pieces may be such that it is easier for the owner player to read them.&ref(fan.png); +There is no need to say "Check" when making a check.&ref(book.png); //+When a player's piece movement was not clear, or was such that it disturbed the arrangements of other pieces, he is required to clarify the move and to rearrange them properly. +Player should refrain from talking to himself, to the opponent, or to third persons needlessly during the game.&ref(fan.png); +It is not recommended to make excessively long thinking for a move too many times, even when the game is not played under time rule.&ref(fan.png);
//+When leaving the seat for a while, such as for going to lavatory, the player should notice the opponent about his leaving and ask for an excuse. //Any other person than the two players must not give any information to the players that would affect the result of the game. Any advice is prohibited. (See Section 4.5) //Drinks, such as tea, are permitted. However, alcohol is generally prohibited during the game. Incidentally, in professional world, one who has been having alcohol is prohibited from entering the game room whether or not he is one of the players or not.
**3.3 Ending the Game [#f2f04725] +The way of making a resignation is not prescribed. However, in professional world, the player usually says "'''Makemashita.'''" (meaning "I have lost."), and makes a slight bow. (also puts his hand on the piece stand sometimes.) The winner then also makes a slight bow. A shogi game starts with courtesy, and ends with courtesy.&ref(fan.png); +After the game, the players should analyze the game and discuss at least for a short time. This is called "'''kansou-sen'''" ("Post-game Analysis"), and is considered to be very important by professional players.&ref(fan.png); +After post-game analysis is over, the superior player puts the pieces back to the piece box, counting the pieces to confirm that no piece is lost. +Before leaving, the players make sincere bows to each other and say "'''Arigatou-gozaimashita.'''" in Japanese, which means "Thank you very much for the game."&ref(fan.png);

*Preface [#hfb94241]
Recently, to our delight, shogi is becoming more and more popular around the world thanks to the efforts by many domestic and overseas shogi fans. Delightful thing as it may, there exists a fear in our mind that the rule system of shogi might be gradually altered and its traditional aspect be forgotten in the long process of its spreading throughout the world. This fear is because of the fact that there is no officially authorized document on the internet at present, especially in English, that clearly prescribes the regulations of shogi.
81Dojo, becoming to have more influence to shogi communities over the world, here would like to take the responsibility and publish the actual rules and manners of shogi, the traditional culture of Japan. The intention of 81Dojo is not to just spread shogi, but to spread it as its genuine form.
This document is a compilation of all the "facts" that are available to know in Japan, such as commonly understood rules and manners, prescribed regulations on subtle details, precedential judgments in professional games, etc. 81Dojo here suggests that this document should always be used as the primary reference when holding any shogi competition overseas.

*Shogi Rules [#v73bed1e] The rules and regulations stated in this Part should be applied to any current shogi competition. When holding a competition with irregular regulations that do not comply with the following, the players must be informed equally before the game.&ref(book.png);
**1.1 Pieces and Spaces [#kbd127c8]
***1.1.1 Pieces &ref(book.png);[#dd448697] The pieces are the fundamental instruments in shogi. A piece is put on the squares on the board, and describes player's moves, which is stated in [[Section 1.3>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Move]].
Shogi has 8 types of pieces, some of them having two states depending on which side is being on top. Head side is for original state, and tail side is for promoted state.
|CENTER:Original State|CENTER:Promoted State|number per player|h |'''Fu''' (Pawn)|'''To-kin''' (Promoted Pawn)|9| |'''Kyou''' (Lance)|'''Nari-kyou''' (Promoted Lance)|2| |'''Kei''' (Knight)|'''Nari-kei''' (Promoted Night)|2| |'''Gin''' (Silver)|'''Nari-gin''' (Promoted Silver)|2| |'''Kin''' (Gold)||2| |'''Kaku''' (Bishop)|'''Uma''' (Horse)|1| |'''Hi''' (Rook)|'''Ryu''' (Dragon)|1| |'''Gyoku''' (King)||1|
Each state of each piece type has unique pattern of movements on the board. See external reference for movement patterns. ([http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shogi#Movement_and_capture Wikipedia, Shogi, Movement and Capture]) During the game, a piece is called with the name written on the top side at the moment, and can be used according to the movement pattern described on that side. Pieces that do not have promoted state cannot be used with their tail sides on top.
Pieces that belong to a player are: +Pieces on the board with their center vertex of pentagon toward the opponent +Pieces on the player's piece stand. (See [[Section 1.1.2>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Spaces]])
***1.1.2 Spaces &ref(book.png); [#Spaces]
The spaces for the pieces to exist consist of the following two.
:"'''shogi-ban'''" (shogi board)|The board has the role of dividing the game space of shogi into sections, and defines the location of each piece. A shogi board is a rectangular plane that has 10 parallel lines at regular intervals in width and depth directions each, thus forms 81 squares for the pieces to exist. No more than one piece can exist on a single square on the board at the same time, regardless of whose piece it is.&br; The series of squares in the depth direction, in other words a column, is called a "'''suji'''" ("file"). On the other hand, a row is called a "'''dan'''" ("rank"), which is in the width direction. The nearest three ranks to a player is called his "own camp", and the farthest three his "opponent's camp". :"'''koma-dai'''" (piece stand)|The space for each player's hand pieces (explained in [[Section 1.3.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#OnBoardMove]]) to be located is called "piece stand". It is used to enhance the convenience in game proceeding.&br;In principle, a player's piece stand should be located on the right side of the board from the player, also being nearer to the player.&ref(fan.png);&br; When piece stands are not available for the game, the players can agree to play without using them, in which case they must put their hand pieces near the side of the board, where both players can easily see.&ref(piece.png);&br; Any number of pieces can exist on one's piece stand, by adding one of opponent's pieces automatically after every time he/she makes a move to capture (See [[Section 1.3.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#OnBoardMove]]) it on a square.
During the game, a piece must stay on any of the 81 squares on the board, or in the spaces for both player's hand pieces. All of these pieces must be always disclosed to each other. **1.2 Game &ref(book.png);[#n7127a2e]
Shogi is a game for only the two players that face each other over the board, to compete with their abilities from the beginning to the end of the competition, making one piece movement (described in [[Section 1.3>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Move]]) at a turn alternately to aim for checkmating (See [[Section 1.5.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Resignation]]) the opponent's king first. The process of making moves until the game-end is called a "'''tai-kyoku'''" (game).
The player who plays first is called "'''sen-te'''", often described by the color "Black", and the other is called "'''go-te'''", "White".
Two players place all their own pieces that are to be used in the game with an agreed handicap level (See [[Section 1.6>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Handicap]]) and sets up the initial piece arrangement, with their head side on top, and with their center vertex of pentagon toward the opponent, so that the owner of the pieces is clear. After that they play the game with the pieces. The game is played all through with only the pieces that were set up initially. Thus, the total number of the pieces does not change during the game.
**1.3 Move [#Move] The two players alternately make moves that are prescribed as moving of pieces from and to spaces of the game under specific rules. The moves during the game are not only their right but also their obligation, thus cannot be renounced. In other words, a player must not pass his turn, and must make one move when he has the turn. At the same time, the player has the freedom in choosing his move.
A move is completed at the instant when the player's hand detaches from the piece that forms the move. Once a move is completed, the player cannot undo nor change the move.&ref(book.png);
Either of the following two actions stated in Section 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 is regarded as a move. No other move than these two can happen.
***1.3.1 On-board Move &ref(book.png);[#OnBoardMove]
This is one of the two types of moves, where a player moves any one of his/her own pieces from a square to another square on the board. Each type of piece can move only with the prescribed unique movement. The orientation of the moving piece never changes during this action.
In this action, there are two restrictions: +The piece cannot move to a square that is already occupied by one of his own pieces. +Except for Knight, a piece cannot make moves that jump over any other pieces, including the player's own and the opponent's.
Attached to this action, one or both of "to capture" and "to promote" can be conducted together. They are defined as one move as a whole.
:Capture &ref(book.png);|During the action stated above, if there exists one of the opponent's piece on the destination square, the player can make the opponent's piece belong to him as his hand piece, and occupy the square instead with his own piece that he has moved. This action is called "to capture".&br; When doing this, the player first removes the opponent's piece on the square and puts it as his own piece on his right outside the board (where his piece stand is), and then moves one of his board pieces to the square that was previously occupied by the opponent's piece. &ref(fan.png);&br; The captured piece belongs to the player as the piece written on its head side, regardless of whether it was head side or tail side up when it was captured. During the game, any piece can capture any piece. It does not happen, however, that a player captures the opponent's King and makes it as his hand piece, as the game must have already ended before that due to the rules stated in [[Section 1.5.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Resignation]].
:Promotion &ref(book.png);|When a piece that has characters written on the tail side, and is currently head side up, has moved on the board with the action stated above TO and/or FROM a square in the opponent's camp, the player has an option of flipping the piece over to let the tail side up at the destination square, its orientation still being as that of his own piece. This action of flipping over the piece is called "to promote", and the piece can then move only as the piece that is written on the tail side after it promoted.&br; Once a piece has been promoted, it cannot be back to original piece by flipping over again as long as the piece exists on the board, no matter what kind of move it ever makes.&br; The player's choosing not to flip over the piece when he has the right to, is called "to unpromote", and the piece's movement remains as its original. In this case, when the unpromoted piece later again meets the requirement to promote, it again has the option of promoting.
***1.3.2 Drop &ref(book.png);[#i615cec6]
This is one of the two types of moves, where a player puts one of his hand pieces ? pieces that he has captured ? back to one of the squares on the board again with its orientation being that of his own piece. A player can drop only one piece on each move. He may choose any one of his hand pieces, and may drop it on any vacant square on the board as long as it is not an illegal drop that is stated in [[Section 1.4>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Illegal]]. A piece must always be dropped with its head side up, regardless of which side was up when it was captured. Once a piece is dropped on the board, it moves the same as the pieces that were initially on the board, and cannot be made back as the player's own hand piece again.
**1.4 Illegal Move [#Illegal] When conducting a move explained in [[Section 1.3>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Move]], the player must avoid making any of the illegal moves explained below.
***1.4.1 Nifu &ref(book.png); [#rdfe0ffa]
"'''Nifu'''", or "Double Pawn", is a move that creates a position where two Pawns of one player exist on the same file with their head sides up. Since a Pawn cannot move sideways, Nifu occurs when a player has dropped a Pawn onto a file that already has one of his other Pawns. However, since a Promoted Pawn is not a Pawn anymore, it is not counted as one of the Pawns that form '''Nifu'''.
***1.4.2 Piece with No Potential Movement on the Board &ref(book.png); [#a0a006ba]
Such a move is prohibited that it creates a piece on the board that has no potential movement destination on the board ever. Here, potential movement destination refers to the squares to which the piece can move, and the squares to which the piece is prevented from moving by other pieces. To be concrete, a Pawn and a Lance cannot exist on the first row from the opponent's side with their head sides up, and likewise a Knight cannot exist on the first and the second row. Creating such a state by dropping or unpromoting the piece forms an illegal move.
***1.4.3 Uchi-fu-zume &ref(book.png); [#x59577f7] '''Uchi-fu-zume''', or "Pawn Drop Mate", refers to a move of dropping a Pawn that creates a checkmate (See [[Section 1.5.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Resignation]]) for the opponent's King at the very position where the Pawn has just been dropped. A Pawn drop that leads to a checkmate only at a later position is not an illegal move. Neither is a checkmate with a Pawn that has just moved on the board.
***1.4.4 Move that Lets the Own King Captured &ref(book.png); [#obf4062d] Such a move is prohibited that it creates a position where one's own King is on a square within the range of opponent pieces' movements. This refers to leaving one's own King in check, moving one's King to opponent's movement range, or removing one's piece that has been blocking an opponent's piece from capturing one's own King.
***1.4.5 Perpetual Check &ref(book.png); [#PerpetualCheck] When an identical position has occurred four times in a game, the position is prohibited for a player if his moves from the first occurrence to the fourth occurrence of the position were all checks. Here, identical position means that all of the following are identical: -the piece deployment on the board -both players' hand pieces -which player has the next turn
It does not matter whether the identical position (i.e. starting point of the recurrence) is the turn of the checking player himself or the other player's.
Perpetual Check is a special exception of Repetition Draw, which is explained in [[Section 1.5.2>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Repetition]].
**1.5 Game End [#GameEnd]
Any of the following states is regarded as a game end. Results such as the winner of the game are decided at the point of game end.
***1.5.1 Resignation &ref(book.png);[#Resignation] A player is allowed to end the game any time on his turn by declaring his own loss, even when none of the following conditions for game end is attained. This is called "'''tou-ryou'''" ("resignation", or "to resign"), and the player who resigned loses the game.
:Checkmate &ref(book.png);|When a player has made a position where at least one of his pieces ? except the King ? has the opponent's King in the range of its movement, (in other words, when he has threatened to capture the opponent’s King in the next move), the player has made an "'''oute'''" (check).&br; A state where the player who has been checked cannot remove the check with any of his next move, (in other words, a state where his King will be captured anyway on the opponent's next move), is called a "'''tsumi'''" (checkmate).&br; The player wins the game when he/she has checkmated the opponent's King first, because it inevitably means that the other player cannot make any legal move from that situation. Thus, the checkmated player must immediately make a resignation when his own King is checkmated. ***1.5.2 Repetition Draw &ref(book.png);[#Repetition]
Four-time occurrence of an identical position in one game is called "Sen-nichi-te" (Repetition), and is a draw except for Perpetual Check that is stated in [[Section 1.4.5>Rules and Manners of Shogi#PerpetualCheck]].
***1.5.3 King Entering &ref(book.png);[#yeda2e96]
Such a state is usually called "'''nyu-gyoku'''", ("King Entering"), as where both players' Kings and some other pieces have entered to the area within three rows from the opponent, so that it is difficult to ever checkmate each other's King.
In this case, the moves would continue for ever without any possibility of checkmating the King ? the primary objective of the game. Thus, when both players have achieved King Entering and there is no possibility for the Kings to be checkmated, (because that both players' other pieces have also entered the opponent's camps and promoted, etc.), the players can agree on suspending the game and decide the winner based on the numbers of the pieces they own.
Piece counting rules is such that: - Rooks and Bishops are 5 points each - Golds, Silvers, Knights, Lances, and Pawns are 1 point each - Kings are not counted
Promoted pieces and hand pieces are counted in the same way as the pieces that are written on their head sides.
If one of the players has less than 24 points, he loses. On the other hand, if both players have 24 points or more, the game ends as a draw. This kind of draw game is called "'''ji-shogi'''" ("Impasse").
//When a game has ended as a draw due to Impasse or Repetition (explained in Section 2.17.4), another game is usually then played from the beginning, Black and White switched. ***1.5.4 Loss by Illegal Act &ref(book.png);[#kcd06063]
A player loses when he/she has violated any of the restrictions stated above, which are:
:Making an illegal move|All illegal moves that are prescribed in [[Section 1.4>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Illegal]].
:Making a wrong way of moving a piece|This includes such situations as where a player has promoted a piece when it cannot, or dropped a piece with its promoted side up.
:Making a move on the opponents turn|This includes Gote's making the first move of the game by mistake.
:Changing a completed move|Player cannot change the move once it is completed, even if he noticed it was a bad move.
The player who has committed any of these illegal acts loses at that point with both players' confirmation on it, only if the result of the game (win/loss, or draw) has not yet been confirmed by other means. &ref(piece.png); (See [[Section 2.3.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Confirmation]])
***1.5.5 Time-up Loss &ref(piece.png);[#TimeUp] In addition to the above, a "time-up" is also one of the types of game end, if the game is played under a time rule. (This will be explained in [[Section 2.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#ThinkingTime]].) **1.6 Handicaps &ref(piece.png); [#Handicap] Handicap is a condition setting before the game, which is based on the difference in playing strength between the players. The only differences that can be set in the conditions are: +Which player has the first turn to play +How much is the difference in the initial numbers of the pieces
All other conditions stated so far do not change as it would alter the game concept of shogi and undermine the equality of two players.
Shogi game is generally played with 20 pieces set up for each player, which is called "'''hira-te'''" ("Even Game"), where sen-te and go-te are decided with a Pawn Toss. (See [[Section 3.1>Rules and Manners of Shogi#StartGame]]) There is also a handicap called "'''jou-sen'''" ("Fixed Black"), where one of the player (the lower ranked of the two) always plays first. As the difference in playing strength widens, the handicap level is enlarged accordingly by removing some of the pieces of the higher ranked player before starting the game. The player who has his piece removed is called "'''uwa-te'''" ("Handicap Giver"), and the other is called "'''shita-te'''" ("Handicap Taker"). The removed pieces are never used in that game. The Handicap Giver should put those pieces back to the piece box before starting the game. In handicaps where some pieces are removed, the Handicap Giver always plays first, although he/she is called by the color "White" in this case for notation reasons.
Handicap types and their standard rank difference -Even Game (with Pawn Toss) … equal rank -Even Game (Fixed Black) … 1-rank difference -Lance Handicap (left Lance removed) … 2-rank difference -Bishop Handicap (Bishop removed) … 3-rank difference -Rook Handicap (Rook removed) … 4-rank difference -Rook-Lance Handicap (Rook, left Lance removed) … 5-rank difference -2-piece Handicap (Rook, Bishop removed) … 6 to 7-rank difference -4-piece Handicap (Rook, Bishop, Lances removed) … 8 to 9-rank difference -6-piece Handicap (Rook, Bishop, Lances, Knights removed) … 10-rank difference
Only the handicaps that are prescribed in Japan Shogi Association's regulation are listed above, although there are other handicap types as well.
All other rules stated so far basically do not change even in handicaps. In point rules in King Entering, however, the points for the removed pieces are added to the handicap giver’s points. *General Competition Rules [#g7fe11d5] **2.1 Thinking Time &ref(piece.png); [#ThinkingTime] In shogi the game will not end unless the players make moves. Since the players cannot be forced to make moves, "thinking time" rule is commonly employed in official competitions, regardless of its being professional or amateur, so that the game proceeds smoothly under equal condition for the players and that the game ends in time as scheduled. Thinking time is usually set before the game as the total available time for each player to use for his turns all through the game. In principle, both players are given equal thinking time, and the consumed time for each turn is subtracted from the players thinking time. As the instrument to measure time, a stopwatch is mainly used in professional competition. In amateur competition, however, a chess clock is rather commonly used. A chess clock is such a device that if one player pushes the button after making his/her move, the clock for the other player starts counting. In other words, one of the two clocks that is for the player who has the turn automatically counts. Thinking time rule systems are roughly classified into "'''byo-yomi'''" ("Extra Time Count") rule and "'''kire-make'''" ("Run-out and Lose") rule.
***2.1.1 Byo-yomi [#v21b65d2]
In this rule, once the given thinking time on the chess clock has run out, a third person (time keeper) counts Byoyomi. However, when chess clocks with Byoyomi function is available, no timer keeper is needed. When the thinking time of a player has run out, the time keeper declares to the player that counting of Byoyomi has started. Time keeper is recommended to use a stopwatch to count Byoyomi, but a wristwatch etc. can be also used if no stopwatch is available. Although Byoyomi is usually 30 seconds or 60 seconds, it can be any length such as 40 seconds etc., and it should be informed to the players beforehand. Byoyomi is counted loud enough to be heard by the players, such as "30 seconds, 40 seconds, 50 seconds, 1, 2, 3, , , 7, 8, 9," in 60 seconds Byoyomi case, for example. Time keeper mechanically counts Byoyomi until the player's move completes. If "10" was counted at last before a move is completed, the player who has had the turn loses due to time-up. Incidentally, if by any chance the piece slipped away from the hand when trying to make a move right before Byoyomi runs out, an alternative action is available for the player to express his next move, in which he points the destination square with his finger and say the name of the piece that he moves/drops to there. When this has happened, counting of Byoyomi is suspended until the current position with the last move is reproduced with the actual pieces on the board. After it is reproduced, time counting restarts for the next player to play.
***2.1.2 Kire-make [#g02298b8] Although this is a rather harsh rule where the player loses immediately when his thinking time has run out, it is becoming more often adopted recently as chess clocks become commonplace, since this rule is more suitable for competitions that need to proceed as scheduled. Even if the player has read the moves to checkmate the opponent's King in his mind, he loses when his thinking time runs out during the moves for the checkmate. Also, even if time-up is noticed after a checkmate is made, it should be rational rather to regard it as a time-up loss, as it is difficult to know when exactly the time ran out. In other words, the player's checkmating move does not become valid until he pushes the clock button after making the move. However, when time-up is noticed after the opponent made an illegal move, the opponent loses due to the illegal move.
***2.1.3 Rules regarding chess clock usage [#d5dabcea] -Chess clock should be placed on such a position that it is easily recognized by both players, is stably placed, and is in equal distance from both players where they can push button easily. -The player who plays second has the right to decide whether the clock is placed on his right or on his left. -A player's thinking time is counted with one of the clocks that is nearer to him. -To start the game, the player who plays second pushes his/her button on the clock first and starts the other clock for the opponent. -For the rest of the moves, each player pushes his/her clock button every time his/her move is made. When doing this, the player must push the button with the same hand (right or left) that he/she used to make the move. This is an important rule, because if the player makes a move with one hand and pushes the button with the other when thinking time is about to run out, fairness in counting thinking time will be undermined. -After a player has completed a move, he/she always has the right to push the button once, even if the opponent has made the next move before doing so. However, a player cannot push the button more than once in one turn, even if he/she did not or forgot to push it in his/her earlier turns. -Except for special cases such as when a notator or a time keeper is attending, the button must be always pushed by its player. The player him/herself is responsible for his/her own thinking time. -If a player arrived late for the game, the time until then is subtracted form his/her thinking time, and then the game starts. Also, it should be decided beforehand that if a player is late for more than a specific length of time, he/she loses by default. (It is possible that both players lose by default, if they both are late.) -It is often misunderstood that the completion of the move is when the button is pushed, and thus the move can be altered if the button is not pushed yet. Since completion of the move is when the player's fingers detached from the piece (as stated earlier), altering the move is considered to be illegal even when it is before pushing the button. Pushing the button should be considered to be apart from the completion of a move. Although chess clock is an important instrument, it only plays a supplementary role in the proceedings of the moves. -For the same reason, it is not prohibited to make the next move when the opponent has been forgetting to push the button after his/her move. -Once the game has ended, both clocks are stopped, and thinking time will not be counted any more. -A rematch after draw game should be played with the remaining thinking time. However, if one of the players has extremely small amount of time left (less than 10 minutes, for example), same amount of additional time is added to both players' thinking time, so that the player who had less thinking time has at least a specific amount of thinking time to start from.
**2.2 27-point Declare System &ref(piece.png);[#n0c5f324]
In order to eliminate any possibility of Impasse draw game, "27-point Rule" is employed in amateur championships today for King Entering games. In 27-point Rule, the player who has less than 27 points loses the King Entering game, as both players have 27 points each at the initial position. If both players have 27 points, White player wins.
Declare System is employed to clarify at which position the pieces should be counted.
The declarer (the player who seeks to declare win), while having the turn to play, first announces his will to declare win before making his next move. And then, he stops the clock and suspends the game.
If the position at that point meets all the requirements listed below, the declarer wins the game.
+Declarer's King is in the opponent's camp. +Declarer has at least 28 points if Black, 27 points if White. +The pieces to be counted are only those in the opponent's camp, and his hand pieces. +Declarer has at least 10 pieces in the opponent's camp other than his King. +Declarer has his thinking time or Byo-yomi left. +Declarer's King is not in check.
If any of the above requirements is not met, the declarer loses the game.
**2.3 Rights and Responsibilities of Players and Third Person &ref(piece.png); [#q4ebd14c]
***2.3.1 Confirmation of Game End [#Confirmation]
When ending the game with any of the conditions stated in [[Section 1.5>Rules and Manners of Shogi#Illegal]], both players' confirmation and agreement on their responsibility is always required.
To do this, however, player may also consult a third person (e.g. the notator) for matters that cannot be confirmed immediately, such as Repetition Draw and Perpetual Check. When the remaining time is extremely small and confirmation is difficult to make, player may stop his/her own clock and make the confirmation.
When a notator attends the game, it is his/her obligation to point out time-up.
Since players' own confirmation is always the primary factor in deciding the result of the game, it can never be changed after once confirmed by both players, even if an illegal act is found after their first agreement. Thus, an already made resignation or agreement has the strongest effect.
&br;
> >> '''Precedent: Kubo vs Gouda (5th Dec. 2006)''' &ref(hammer.png); -When both players cannot agree on the result, it should be consulted with a person who has the authority. (Also see [[Appendix Chapter 3, Article 8, Clause 4 >Rules and Manners of Shogi#A-3-8]]) -Any forced game end should be pointed out before a resignation.
> >> In Gouda's 126th move, Kubo believed that Byoyomi had run out before the move was made. But since the notator did not declare time-up and Kubo himself was in Byoyomi as well, he could not make up his mind to point it out at the time and kept playing. After 182nd move, where Kubo was in a losing position, he asked to suspend the game and pointed out that 126th move was a time-up. The notator consulted JSA Vice Chairman Makoto Nakahara with the matter. Nakahara's judgement was that pointing out time-up later is not valid. The game was then restarted, right after which Kubo resigned.
&br;
> >> '''Precedent: Abe vs Katou (10th May 2005)''' &ref(hammer.png); -An already made resignation or agreement has the strongest effect.
> >> Right after Katou played △N-37= in 100th move, he kept on fiddling with the Knight touching it again and again for several seconds, and then flipped it over to be △N-37+. Abe, instead of claiming an illegal act of changing a completed move, only claimed that thinking time should be properly subtracted because the clock had stopped since when Katou played △N-37=. Thinking time was then subtracted, and the game kept on proceeding, in which Abe resigned in the end. JSA later imposed penalty on Katou for making the illegal act of changing a completed move. However, the result of the game remained as Katou's win. ***2.3.2 Voluntary Advice by Third Person [#z94fe89f]
Any third person (e.g. spectators) must not give any advice to players.
However, he/she does have the right to point out any forced game end when it is clear, such as illegal move and time-up, etc.&ref(book.png); It should then be followed by both players' confirmation to decide the result of the game.
&br;
> >> '''Precedent: Ariyoshi vs Tanaka (TV broadcast "Haya-zashi" (Blitz) Championship)''' &ref(hammer.png); -A third person can point out illegal move.
> >> After Ariyoshi made a Nifu in the game, Tanaka kept thinking for the next move not noticing it was Nifu. The notator, Woman Professional Player Yamato Takahashi, then declared a game end based on the illegal move. *Traditional Procedures & Cultural Manners [#v4acf661]
**3.1 Starting the Game [#StartGame] +Usually, one of the two players acts as the "superior player" all through the game. Superior usually means the higher ranked or the elder. +The superior player of the two takes the seat of honor, if there is one. +The superior player opens the piece box, and gently spreads the pieces near on the center of the board. +The superior player first puts his King ("'''Oushou'''", the higher ranked King piece) to the specified square.&ref(fan.png); +The other player should wait quietly without touching any of the pieces. Only after the superior player has put his King, then he may take his King ("'''Gyoku-shou'''", the lower ranked King piece) and put it.&ref(fan.png); +There is no rule regarding how to set up other pieces than the Kings. In professional world, however, Oh-hashi Style or Itoh Style is usually used to set up the pieces in order.&ref(fan.png); (See external reference: [[Wikipedia, Shogi, Piece Setup Order>http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E9%A7%92_(%E5%B0%86%E6%A3%8B)#.E4.B8.A6.E3.81.B9.E6.96.B9.E3.81.AE.E4.BD.9C.E6.B3.95]]) +A player should set up only his own pieces. It is against manner to setup the opponent's pieces.&ref(fan.png); +After both players have put all their pieces to the initial position, the superior player puts the rest of the pieces back to the piece box, and puts it away. If the game is with a handicap, the superior player also removes some of his own pieces as well and put them in the piece box. In professional games, the piece box is usually put under the board. +In case of an Even Game, the superior player makes a "'''furi-goma'''" (Pawn Toss), and decides who plays first. To make a Pawn Toss, the player picks up five Pawns of his (usually the center pawns), and shakes them in his hands, and then throws it on the board or any plane near the players.&ref(fan.png);&br; If the number of the pieces with their head sides up is more than that of tail sides up, then the player who made the Pawn Toss plays first, and vice versa. If any piece stands on its edge or some pieces are stacked, all of those pieces are not counted. And if the numbers of heads and tails were the same, the player tosses all five Pawns again. &ref(piece.png); +The players make polite greetings, and then start the game. "'''Onegai-shimasu.'''" (or "'''Yoroshiku onegai-shimasu.'''") is the common Japanese word for greetings.&ref(fan.png);
**3.2 During the Game [#m2ea5aba]
+While thinking for the next move, a player should not keep holding his hand pieces in his hand, nor be touching the pieces on the board (except for when rearranging the positions of pieces that are disturbed.) A hand piece should be held only when it is about to be dropped. Also, a player should not repeat the action of making the same move, snapping the piece to the board again and again.&ref(fan.png); +Player's fingers should be released from the piece immediately after a move is made.&ref(fan.png); +One should start moving his piece only after the opponent's move is completed. It is impolite to start making a move before the opponent's finger detach from his piece.&ref(fan.png); +When capturing an opponent's piece, one should first gently pick up and place it on his piece stand, and then move his own piece to there.&ref(fan.png);&br; During this action, it is disgraceful to put the opponent's piece back to its square and think again, although the move is not considered to be completed at this point according to the rules. One should think carefully enough before making any action.&ref(fan.png);&br; +Player should not use both hands when capturing a piece. (Especially in a game with chess clocks.&ref(piece.png); ) +Hand pieces should be placed with their head sides up, and be arranged neatly so that the opponent can easily see them. The orientation of the hand pieces may be such that it is easier for the owner player to read them.&ref(fan.png); +There is no need to say "Check" when making a check.&ref(book.png); //+When a player's piece movement was not clear, or was such that it disturbed the arrangements of other pieces, he is required to clarify the move and to rearrange them properly. +Player should refrain from talking to himself, to the opponent, or to third persons needlessly during the game.&ref(fan.png); +It is not recommended to make excessively long thinking for a move too many times, even when the game is not played under time rule.&ref(fan.png);
//+When leaving the seat for a while, such as for going to lavatory, the player should notice the opponent about his leaving and ask for an excuse. //Any other person than the two players must not give any information to the players that would affect the result of the game. Any advice is prohibited. (See Section 4.5) //Drinks, such as tea, are permitted. However, alcohol is generally prohibited during the game. Incidentally, in professional world, one who has been having alcohol is prohibited from entering the game room whether or not he is one of the players or not.
**3.3 Ending the Game [#f2f04725] +The way of making a resignation is not prescribed. However, in professional world, the player usually says "'''Makemashita.'''" (meaning "I have lost."), and makes a slight bow. (also puts his hand on the piece stand sometimes.) The winner then also makes a slight bow. A shogi game starts with courtesy, and ends with courtesy.&ref(fan.png); +After the game, the players should analyze the game and discuss at least for a short time. This is called "'''kansou-sen'''" ("Post-game Analysis"), and is considered to be very important by professional players.&ref(fan.png); +After post-game analysis is over, the superior player puts the pieces back to the piece box, counting the pieces to confirm that no piece is lost. +Before leaving, the players make sincere bows to each other and say "'''Arigatou-gozaimashita.'''" in Japanese, which means "Thank you very much for the game."&ref(fan.png);
[1] 将棋ガイドブック(Shogi Guidebook), Japan Shogi Association, 2003, ISBN 4-8197-0080-4

revision.text:
'''Такахаси Ямато''' ([http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高橋和 高橋 和]) - профессионалка сёги, 3-й женский дан. Родилась 17 июня 1976 года. В рамках данного проекта известна своим указанием на [[кинтэ]] во время партии Ариёси-Танака, попавшим в [[кодекс Хидэтчи]].
[[Категория:Сёгисты]]

revision.text:
'''Бёёми''' (秒読み, "отсчёт секунд") - дополнительное время, которое наступает, когда основное время игрока заканчивается. После окончания основного времени игрок обязан сделать ход за отведённый период (обычно 30-60 секунд), иначе он проигрывает.
[[Категория:Термины сёги]]
